essential oils from the leaves of eucalyptus deglupta and other related aromatic plants were reported to inhibit the growth of pseudomonas aeruginosa.

eucalyptus deglupta (blume) of the family myrtaceae, commonly known as mindanao gum or rainbow eucalyptus, is native to the philippines and other western pacific islands, adapting well in lowland humid tropical conditions and reaching up to 100 ft in height.

eucalyptus deglupta is cultivated throughout the world as an ornamental tree, noted for its spectrum of colors developed by the peeling of its smooth bark in a fatigueinspired pattern, revealing multi-colored streaks of yellow, red, blue, orange, green, purple, brown, and gray shades 5-hydroxy-7,4'-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone, 2]. the genus eucalyptus has been a traditional source of timber, cellulose-related products and essential oils from the leaves [3, 4]. an antihypertensive food and food additive containing an extract prepared from eucalyptus plants was reported.
eucalyptus deglupta was reported to exhibit a high percentage of xanthine oxidase inhibition (ic50 of 44.5 g/ml) and also prevented cataract development in streptozotocin diabetic rats.

phloroglucinol derivatives from eucalyptus have growth regulatory, antigranulation, antiinflammatory and antimalarial activities, while rutin and other flavonoids, terpenoids and tannins from eucalyptus are of great pharmaceutical importance.

sample collection samples of leaves and twigs of eucalyptus deglupta (blume) were a generous gift collected from the center for ecozoic living and learning (cell), silang, cavite in may 2014.
silica gel chromatography of the dichloromethane extract of the twigs of eucalyptus deglupta (blume) led to the isolation of 5-hydroxy-7,4'-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone .

the 13 c nmr spectrum of 5-hydroxy-7,4'-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone, gave resonances for a conjugated carbonyl carbon at 183.27; oxygenated aromatic carbons at 163.88, 162.58 (2c), 157.29 and 153.00; protonated aromatic carbons at 128.00 (2c), 114.56 (2c) and 104.09; four non-protonated aromatic carbons at 123,9, 114.10, 108.78 and 107.40; methoxy carbons at 60.51 and 55.53; and methyl carbons at 8.57 and 8.

the 30% acetone in ch2cl2 fraction was rechromatographed (3 ) in 20% etoac in petroleum ether to afford 5-hydroxy-7,4'-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone, (7 mg) after washing with petroleum ether, followed by et2o.

the 5-hydroxy-7,4'-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone, h nmr spectrum of 5-hydroxy-7,4'-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone, indicated resonances for two aromatic methyl singlets at 2.20 and 2.38; methoxy groups at 3.78 and 3.88; a deshielded olefinic proton singlet at 6.61; aromatic proton doublets at 7.02 (2h) and 7.86 (2h) othro coupled to each other by 9 hz which was confirmed by cosy; and a chelated oh at 12.
the crude extract from the leaves were fractionated by silica gel chromatography using increasing proportions of acetone in dichloromethane (10% increment) as eluents.

the essential oils from the dried leaves of five species of the genus eucalyptus (eucalyptus camaldulensis, eucalyptus deglupta, eucalyptus grandis, eucalyptus torelliana, eucalyptus urophylla) were found to contain as major components the following terpenes: alpha-pinene, beta-pinene, alpha-phellandrene, limonene, -terpinene, p-cymene and beta-caryophyllene.
the extracts also afforded a low molecular weight si containing compound which is effective in inhibiting hiv-1 virus.
the isolation of ursolic acid, oleanolic acid, and squalene from the leaves and twigs and nerolidol from the leaves of eucalyptus deglupta have been reported.

the ortho coupled protons could only be in ring c of the flavone skeleton at c-2', c-3', c-5' and c-6', while the chelated hydroxyl could only be attached to c-5. one of the methoxy groups was attached to c4' on the basis of long-range correlations between this methoxy, the ortho aromatic protons and c-4'. the position of the hydroxyl proton was confirmed by correlations with c-5, c-6 and c-10.

the protons attached to carbon atoms were assigned from hsqc 2d nmr data (see experimental), and the structure of 5-hydroxy-7,4'-dimethoxy-6,8-dimethylflavone, was elucidated by analysis of the hmbc 2d nmr data.
